data.stimulus:
Seminar Discussion - Identifying Viewpoints

Listen to Rachel (speaker A), Sania (speaker B) and Sean (speaker C) discussing the seminar topic "Gender Equality in the Workplace is Achievable"

 

 

► For each speaker, decide whether they are mainly FOR the topic (they agree with it) or AGAINST (they disagree with it).

data.template:
Identifying Evidence 

► In an academic discussion you need to support your arguments with {{response}} from suitable sources. This makes your argument {{response}} and more academic.

stems: Someone has to stay at home to look after the children
A scheme in Germany offers parents two thirds of their salary for up to 14 months, if they take time off work to look after a baby – and it is open to mothers or fathers
A lot of people don’t like the policy because it's paid for by employers and employees
All members of the family benefit from fathers being able to share in childcare
We’re looking at a better work-life balance for men and women and then deciding between childcare and career doesn’t depend on gender
Women still hold fewer higher positions. This is even in careers, like teaching, where there are more women overall

The main problem is stereotyping and a lack of good female role models. It says that even when they are children, women start to believe that they can’t behave in certain ways, or choose certain subjects at school.
If they were more aware of positive examples, of women succeeding in traditionally male-dominated careers, this could give women the confidence to challenge stereotypes
A lot of women actually have to work harder than men to achieve the same position
In these cases, the women are clearly very ambitious and very capable
The system can be the issue (sexism in institutions) not differences in individual attitude or ability
data.stimulus:
► In the discussion above the participants referred to the texts 'Parental Leave' and 'Still Hitting the Ceiling', which you studied in your previous online lesson. 

 

Read the arguments below - they were used in the discussion above.

For each argument, decide if they were...

► Based on evidence from sources (the participant gives information from a cited source) 
► Evaluation based on evidence (the participant gives their opinion based on cited evidence)
► No evidence (the participant does not cite a source to support what they are saying)      

 

(watch the video again to check!)

possible_responses: using the exact words in the source
data.stimulus:
Paraphrasing in Speaking 

When speakers use evidence from sources in a seminar discussion or a presentation, they need to paraphrase key ideas.
data.template: ► This means {{response}} to express the ideas in the texts you read when you are researching for your assignments.

options.label: it shows you understand the source.
it helps the speaker to avoid plagiarism.
it helps other participants to understand the key ideas so they can respond and continue the discussion.
it makes you sound smart and intelligent.

data.stimulus:
This is important because...

(choose THREE)

In the next activity, you are going to practise expressing the same idea in different words.

► Below are some extracts from the discussion and some paraphrases. Read them carefully.

► Match each extract with the correct paraphrase.

 

Extracts
  • Extract 1 - In 2007, Germany improved its parental leave policy to give new parents two-thirds of their salary for up to 12 months or up to 14 months, if at least two months of the 'Babypause' is taken by the father
  • Extract 2 - The scheme is not without its critics in Germany - particularly with regard to the costs of the policy, which is largely funded by social insurance
  • Extract 3 - The benefits of father-friendly policies are numerous. Fathers are better able to spend time with their children. Children benefit from increased parental time. Mothers are better able to achieve a balance between home life and work.
  • Extract 4 - Children as young as five already have stereotypical beliefs about what constitutes men's and women's work. It is clear that the home and school environments influence not only young girls' vision of their role in society, but also their assertiveness and willingness to undertake experimentation, self-motivated exploration and risk-taking... These factors influence girls' choice of subjects at school...
  • Extract 5 - They often find they have to work harder and be better qualified than their male counterparts in order to be selected for or promoted to high positions... Seniority in academic positions for women tends to require more items of merit... 

Paraphrases 
  • Paraphrase A  - Even when they are children, women start to believe that they can’t behave in certain ways, or choose certain subjects at school (ESRC, 2010). 
  • Paraphrase B  - All members of the family benefit from fathers being able to share in childcare (ESRC, 2010).
  • Paraphrase C  - A lot of women actually work harder than men and have to achieve more to reach the same position (ESRC, 2010).
  • Paraphrase D  - Some people don’t like the policy because it is paid for by employers and employees (ESRC, 2010).
  • Paraphrase E  - A scheme in Germany, which offers parents two thirds of their salary for up to 14 months, if they take time off work to look after a baby and that is open to mothers or fathers (ESRC, 2010).

Verbal Citations

In order to avoid plagiarism, you also need to use verbal citations in seminar discussions and presentations. 

Complete the following bullet points describing WHY you need citations and HOW to do them!
data.template:
WHY do you need to use Verbal Citations?

► THREE reasons:

  • {{response}}: your argument will be more persuasive (and academic) if you refer to reliable sources in your speaking.
  • {{response}}: you should always acknowledge where your ideas come. If you do not do this, you are 'stealing' ideas (plagiarism).
  • {{response}}: your audience will know where they can find more information, if they wish to research any of the ideas you discuss.

 

HOW do you Cite Verbally?

► Include information about your source:

  • {{response}}: whose ideas are you citing?
  • {{response}}: where can we find these ideas?
  • {{response}}: were the ideas published in a reliable source?
  • {{response}}: are the ideas up-to-date?

data.stimulus:
Verbal Citations - an example

► Look at this example of a verbal citation.

► Identify the different types of information provided by the speaker.

Verbal Citations 

Below are three examples of verbal citations from the seminar discussion on Equal Opportunities.

Complete the examples by putting the words in the correct order.
data.template: {{response}} {{response}} produced by {{response}} {{response}} {{response}}, women still hold less of the higher positions.

value: ‘Helping fathers stay at home is key to equality’

value: ‘Helping fathers stay at home is key to equality’

data.template: {{response}} , {{response}} {{response}} , {{response}}{{response}}{{response}} that many girls are not even informed about career opportunities in construction when they are at school.

value: Either parent can do it, if both parents can receive government support
There are a lot of benefits
Benefits are for ALL the family
Women are not in low positions because they lack ambition
Women are not in low positions because they lack ambition and stereotyping is an issue
There are fewer women in higher positions because of stereotyping and lack of role‑models
